Expectation1: Take and record vital signs like temperature, pulse, and blood pressure
Situation1: A patient is recovering from a recent procedure and has slightly elevated vital signs.
Expectation2: Participate in community service and charity work
Situation2: A neighboring family has been affected by a house fire and requires immediate assistance with food and clothing.
Story: I stood at the foot of Mr. Garcia’s bed, my stethoscope pressed gently to his chest. His pulse was a little fast, his temperature just above normal. The nurse had asked me to keep a close watch and record every change, no matter how small. I knew how important it was—one missed sign could mean a setback in his recovery. As I finished jotting down his numbers, my phone buzzed in my pocket. It was Sister Maria: the family next door had lost their home in a fire. They needed help now—food, blankets, someone to comfort the children. My heart twisted. As a nun, I was expected to be there, to serve and bring hope in moments of crisis. But as a nursing assistant, I couldn’t leave my post; Mr. Garcia depended on me. The weight of both uniforms pressed on my shoulders, each demanding my presence, each equally urgent. I stood frozen, torn between the quiet beeping of the monitor and the desperate call for compassion just beyond the hospital walls.
